title: Clinical Management of a Patient with a Folded Electrode Array
chief_complaint: I'm having trouble understanding speech with my right implant, and my left implant has a 'hollow' sound quality. I hear noises like music and engines in my head, but they don't bother me too much.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual hearing loss over 25 years; loss of residual low-frequency hearing in right ear after initial hybrid implantation.
problem_summary.course: Received right Hybrid CI in 2007 (FDA trial) and left Standard CI in 2008. Stopped using acoustic component in right ear due to progression of loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (music, voices, engine noise); history of dizziness/disequilibrium after left ear surgery.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Limited speech recognition in the right ear; satisfactory benefit but poor sound quality in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Improve speech understanding and sound quality, though initially apprehensive about revision surgery due to fear of dizziness.

history.present_illness: Patient presented for reprogramming. Right ear had a S8 Hybrid (10mm, 6 electrodes) device (implanted 2007) but lost residual hearing, rendering the acoustic component useless. Left ear had a Freedom Contour (implanted 2008).
history.otologic_history: History of gradual hearing loss (25 years). Bilateral HA use for 23 years prior to CIs.
history.medical_psych_history: History of dizziness and disequilibrium following left CI surgery.
history.prior_management: Bimodal fitting initially, then bilateral CI. Declined right ear revision in 2008 due to dizziness fears.

numeric_results.Left_ear: No measurable hearing reported in text

tests.name: Sound-field Thresholds
tests.key_findings: Right hybrid CI performance was poor compared to the left standard CI.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: AzBio sentences in quiet at 60 dB SPL showed significant asymmetry in performance.

history.prior_management: FAT adjusted (upper cutoff 6000 Hz, lower 70 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: No significant change in speech recognition.

history.prior_management: Decision to explant Hybrid and reimplant with Standard array.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.key_findings: Right Hybrid CI leads in good position. Left CI showed electrode 'fold-over' in the ascending limb of the basal turn.

tests.name: Vestibular Assessment
tests.key_findings: Normal vestibular function bilaterally (VNG and CDP).

history.present_illness: Follow-up 6 months after right ear revision surgery (explant of Hybrid, reimplant with Standard array).
history.prior_management: Right ear reimplanted. Full insertion achieved. Activated 1 month post-op.

tests.name: Sound-field Thresholds
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement in detection thresholds with new standard array.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear performance surpassed the left ear. Patient reported 'fuller' sound quality.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presented with profound bilateral SNHL. Initially, the right ear (Hybrid device) provided minimal benefit (10% speech recognition) due to loss of residual acoustic hearing, while the left ear (Standard device) provided good benefit (76%) despite a confirmed electrode fold-over. Following reimplantation of the right ear with a standard array, speech recognition improved dramatically to 92%, surpassing the left ear and providing a fuller sound quality.
counseling_points: Because you have lost the natural low-pitch hearing in your right ear, the Hybrid device is no longer providing the benefit it once did.
Replacing the right Hybrid device with a standard cochlear implant is likely to significantly improve your speech understanding.

Regarding your left ear: Although the scan shows the electrode is folded, you are performing very well with it. We generally do not recommend replacing a functioning implant that provides good speech scores.
Your dizziness evaluation is normal, which is reassuring regarding the risks of a second surgery, though we will monitor you closely.
notes_for_actor: You are 78 years old and generally happy with your left implant, though it sounds a bit 'hollow'.
You are very nervous about dizziness because you had a bad experience after your left ear surgery years ago.
You are initially hesitant about another surgery but willing to proceed if it helps you understand speech better on your right side.
